review.title: Active Learning for Matching Problems
review.abstract: Effective learning of user preferences is critical to easing user burden in various types of matching problems. Equally important is active query selection to further reduce the amount of preference information users must provide. We address the problem of active learning of user preferences for matching problems, introducing a novel method for determining probabilistic matchings, and developing several new active learning strategies that are sensitive to the specific matching objective. sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: We explored the problem of active learning for comparative referral systems. We explored various approaches to generating queries that align with the matching target, and introduced a new method of probabilistic matching that takes into account uncertainties in predicted outcomes. Experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our methods in determining high-quality matches with significantly lower user preferences than those required by uncertainty samples, a standard active learning method. Our results highlight the importance of selecting queries in a way that responds sensitively to the matching target and uncertainty about predicted outcomes. There are many promising opportunities for future research on comparatively limited recommendations. We are currently investigating various matching targets (e.g. bilateral matching with stability limitations) and methods to obtain page information from users in a way that aligns with the referral target. Finally, overarching, abstract queries (such as preferences to preferences) can significantly increase user performance.
